projects.name: Gestural Lamp1
projects.description_short: A traditional Japanese lamp that responds gesturally to weather phenomena.
projects.description_long: A traditional Japanese lamp that responds gesturally to weather phenomena using an integrated micro controller + Connectivity to remote weather stations. The lamp seeks to explore our relationship with dynamic data, for this instance weather. How much do we really need to know? When is a qualitative understanding of data sufficient? The lamp is also a sort of commentary on the current state of culture in Japan. It is no coincidence that the lamp resembles a tower crane. The lamp bridges the gap between traditional Japanese culture and Japan as a world-leading technological hub. The Lamp is a collaboration between Massart’s graphic design program and MIT’s Architectural Computation department. The following pages detail the CAD models and a bit of the building process for the first of the 3 proposed lamps, this is the smallest desk lamp. Further on there is a glimpse into the program written to aggregate weather sources as well as a web-interface designed to program + control the lamp.

bios_text.title:
Designer | Researcher
Creative Coder
bios_text.description_short: My work explores the intersection of design and technology, weaving lessons from natural systems into creative solutions and computational models.
bios_text.description_long:
I recently completed my undergraduate studies in Boston, MA achieving a BFA with highest honors while attending Massachusetts College of Art & Design (MassArt) and Massachusetts Intstitute of Technology (MIT). Resume.
I am fascinated by ubiquitous computing and the emerging ‘Internet of Things’ [iot] movement. My current research explores how advancements in artificial intelligence will revolutionize user experience by transforming quanitive data into qualitative insights.
